title: 103_hr3810
content: The "Rural Community Wastewater Treatment Affordability Act of 1994" amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to include acquisition of lands, easements, and rights-of-ways necessary for construction of treatment works. It also expands eligibility for assistance to provide wastewater treatment and water supply services to communities. SEC. 3. CAPITALIZATION GRANT AGREEMENTS. Amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to encourage the use of innovative and cost-effective technologies in the construction of treatment works financed with assistance provided from the fund. The loan program under the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to provide loans to rural and disadvantaged communities at or below market interest rates, including interest-free and negative-interest loans, with terms not exceeding 40 years or the useful life of the project. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allocate 15 percent of all loans from the water pollution control revolving fund for negative-interest loans to rural and disadvantaged communities. Additionally, grants will be provided to these communities for planning purposes. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to allocate grants to rural and disadvantaged communities for planning and predevelopment costs related to construction or improvement of treatment works. Grants will cover up to 75 percent of costs, with a limit of $75,000 per project. In this title, definitions for rural and disadvantaged communities are provided, excluding areas with a population over 10,000 and residents with a household income above 75% of the national median. A negative-interest loan is defined as a loan with an interest rate below zero, provided by a State to such communities for water pollution control projects. The State offers a zero percent interest rate loan with forgiveness of up to 2 percent of the principal per year, not exceeding 20 percent over the loan term. SEC. 5 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act regarding administrative costs not exceeding 4 percent of total funds deposited. SEC. 6 introduces a technical assistance grant program under Title VI of the Act. The Administrator may provide grants to organizations for training and technical assistance to rural communities on treatment works. $15,000,000 per fiscal year is authorized for fiscal years 1994 through 1998. A conforming amendment is made to Section 607 of the Act.
